Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Timely Assessment of Water Quality to Reveal the Potential Ecological and Health Impact of Hurricanes at Puerto Rico

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1810769 Gu, April

Back-to-back hurricanes in Puerto Rico have caused much of the sewage treatment infrastructure on the island to be non-operational. As a result, raw sewage and other contaminants have been released into coastal waters, streams, and rivers. Understanding the impact of catastrophic events like hurricanes on water distribution systems requires rapid data acquisition soon after the event. The goal of this project is to provide water quality toxicity data to assess the recovery process in Puerto Rico's drinking water supply and surface water. This will be done using novel state-of-the-art toxicity assays developed by the research team. The results of this research will provide a one-of-a-kind opportunity to quantify risks to public health during recovery.

The study will apply next-generation, toxicogenomics-enabled in vitro assays for timely and informative water quality monitoring, coupled with strain-resolved metagenomic data to identify risks originating from the presence of host of microbial pathogens. The results have the potential to lead to a paradigm shift in water remediation efficacy assessment from older methods that frequently suffer from bias and limited chemical and microbiological information. This will provide timely and useful information needed to facilitate containment and response strategies development and, to help inform the public and government of any potential ecological and health impacts associated the recent extreme weather events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of the project was to assess the impact of Hurricanes Irma and Marie on the drinking water quality in Puerto Rico. The proposed study applied a next-generation, toxicogenomics-enabled in vitro assay scheme and methodology platform,  coupled strain-resolved metagenomic data, to provide an effective toxicity evaluation methods for timely and informative water quality monitoring, as urgently needed by incidents like hurricanes in Puerto Rico.This study performed a comprehensive assessment of the impact of HM on drinkingwater quality and toxicity in PR by integrating targeted chemical analysis of bothinorganic (18 trace elements) and organic trace pollutants (200 micropollutants) with high-throughput (HTS) quantitative toxicogenomics and in vitro biomarkers-based toxicity assays. The results indicated that,in overall, drinking water in PR showed relatively higher contamination levels after the HM with respect to both chemicaland toxicity effects.Correlation analysis and Maximum Cumulative Ratio assessment suggested thatmetals (i.e. As) and PFOA were the top ranked pollutants that have the potential tocause increased risk after HM, providing a possible direction for post-disaster waterresource management and epidemiological studies.The results provide  useful information needed to facilitate containment and response strategies development and, to help inform the public and government of any potential ecological and health impacts associated the extreme weather events.The project integrates multidisciplinary approaches including environmental engineering, toxicology, microbiology, chemistryand bioinformatics. So the outcome of this project demonstrated the effective and useful application of other fields for solvingenvironmental challenges and problems. The project integrated diverse disciplines of biotechnology, toxicology, andenvironmental engineering to open new ground for timely and cost-effective water quality and risk asssement foremergencies and disaster events.  The outcome contributes to the development of feasible and reliable methods to provide timely and informative informationand tools for hazard and risk assessment for public health protection.
